element_texts.text:
Hi Folks -

 See your name in the paper every now and then, Mr. C. Hope things are all right with the original G.S.G.  I am back in college studying computer technology - just one of those light bored-house-wife curicula.   Our baby is six feet tall and a senior in high school.   Have included a shot of the old folks at home - Fran and me - taken on my birthday.  The fortieth - gasp!  Happy Holidays!

October  3, 1964
Dear Mr. & Mrs. Conroy,
this evening, Gus demanded the crayon box of his father and, when asked for what purpose, replied, "I gotta write a ledder to Mr. Conroy." the result of his efforts is enclosed and we know you will want to display it with your other original art.

  "Slappy" arrived, prophetically, as I was wiping the paint from Gus's hands for what must have been the eleventh time after he assisted in the redecoration of

the front hall.  Fran says that if more painters were favored with such help, the union would pay them.

  I really enjoyed reading the book and Gus is especially fond of the cowboy, train, and fire engine pictures, pointing them out repeatedly to the cat and his fleet of teddy bears.  We are really honored to own an autographed copy; it was very thoughtful of you to send it.
  I know Mother and Dad enjoyed visiting with you the other evening, as we did, and we hope to see you again.  (over)

Thanks once more for introducing us to the world's fastest.
Fran, Merry Ann, & Gus

penciled notation in top margin:  Dolowy 
Dear Conroys,

 If, at first, you don't recognize these two old friends, we will admit that they have undergone considerable change since your last meeting.   the table, Early Green Street, circa 1950, has been sandblasted, hand sanded, steel wooled, and lovingly treated to a natural finish.  We are looking forward to using it for at least as many years as you folks did.
  The individual on the right is now a first grader complete with skinned knees and spaces rather than teeth.  Just out of sight on the left is our cat, Lucille, who remains reticent about being photographed despite

her "Furriest Cat" award from the common cat show.

  Fran and I enjoy restoring old furniture and you can't imagine how many compliments your table has reaped.   We have one of the original cherubs from the Riverview Carousel hanging on the wall near it and they compliment each other very nicely.   We go "junking" every now and then to houses about to be razed and occasionally make a real find.   Mother has described your interesting house for us.  Of course, now that she and I have the convenience of new homes, we have become very sentimental about some of the long lost old fashioned things.   Just nail down those griffons should you see an old hearse with flowers on the shades pull up - that's our hauling fun-car.
  Have a pleasant holiday season.  

Merry Ann

postmark  CHICAGO ILL.  LINCOLN PARK STA.  JAN   23 11 AM  1946
Mr. Jack Conroy
Consolidated Publishers
153 No. Michigan
Chicago

pencil notation in top margin  Donovan, Dianne
letterhead  Chicago Tribune  435 North Michigan Avenue.  Chicago.  Illinois  60611-4041

                       Dianne Donovan  Books Editor  312/222-4125

Dear Jack Conroy,
Here's the book.  As I mentioned on the phone, about 500 words should be fine.   The deadline is Nov. 21, and the pay is $100. 
I certainly enjoyed the stories in The Weed King last year - did you get a copy of the Tribune review?
Thanks again for agreeing to review The Damndest Radical.  Please put your Social Security number on the review.
Yours sincerely.
Dianne

pencil notation in top margin:  Doray, Leon
San Francisco
Sept. 2, 1934
Dear Jack Conroy:

  Whether or not you remember my name I dont know but back on June 3rd you took the time to write me a long letter which, I am very much ashamed to say, I have never answered.  Before I go any farther however I had better explain the snotty little squib pinned to this letter.   I tried to get some publicity on THE DISINHERITED and that was the best I was able to do, proving the great influence I have in the S.F.   literary world.  (The clipping is from the Argonaut, one of the worst weeklies in the U.S.).  While I am apologizing I had better admit that I have not yet read THE DISINHERITED, although I did read some of the extracts in the Mercury.
   The rest of this is business.   The Artists and Writers Union, 325 Kearny Street, S. F., is opening a magazine shop, for the very good reason that there is no place out here where one can buy any of the so-called little mags, either proletarian of "literary" (with the exception of a very few of the better known ones), and we would like you to send us a bundle of 5 copies of the last issue to start with.   As I understand it the usual procedure is to remit the amount of money due for the copies sold at the time of each new issue, at the same time mailing back (at  our expense) the covers of all unsold copies, and in case you want unsold copies returned intact the postage is deducted from the remittance.  Correct?   Also, dont forget to tell us what our MARGIN OF PROFIT  is!
   A bit of rush service on this would be much appreciated.

Sincerely,
signature:  Leon Doray
Leon Doray
(Recording Sec'y, A&WU
P.S.  How are you fixed for mss?  I thought you'd be full up so I didnt send anything.
Could you tell us where we could get a list of all the better little mags in the country?

postcard 
Dorinson   28 Springfield Pike
Wyoning, Ohio
postmark   CINCINNATI, OHIO 2  1949  SEP 13 8 - PM
Mr Jack Conroy
6012 Green St.
Chicago, Illinois

Tues
Dear Jack
How I wish I could join you in that mad round of gaiety and pleasure tendered to J. Light!  Please, don't sit in that vacant chair!
Z

in pencil in top margin:  Dorinson, A. 
10-11-55
Dear Jack

  They love Slappy Hooper and the Fast Sooner Hound in the Heights - as I found out when talking to the librarian of the children's section!*  So much so that she wondered if you'd talk to the kiddies - what with National Book Week coming on and all.  Catch - no money involved.   If you could possibly be interested in such an unexciting proposal - a formal invite will be forthcoming.
   Incidentally, the Dorinsons invite you (not formally) to view a semi-fitted Dorinson house - our own - 1746 W. 189th St., Homewood, Ill.   We are here, building; you pick a date if you can find one, because here we are, 

They have a Carnegie Library.

building.  Seriously, could we interest you in coming out with the Nyvalls when they drive out?  We would be real happy to see you and Gladys.
Sincerely,
Z Dorinson
Note new add.  1746 W. 189th St.  Homewood, Ill.

[pencil notation in top margin:   1950s]]
Wednesday
Have room for numerous Conroys and Lights and am even now laying in a supply of picture wire.   Either Friday or Saturday is wonderful - and then just plan to stay a while, huh?
Love, Z

pencil notation in top margin   Dorinson, Dorry  [1974]
Dear Jack and Gladys -

 1975 will be, I hope, my last year on the job.  June 1 is my goal as a retirement date.  After that Zena and I plan to build on our property on Exuma, one of the Bahama Islands, and try living in a less crowded, less polluted, quieter environment.
   Helen Biebel, who lives in Miami and is a part-time librarian, sent us the tear sheets from a library journal which carried an article by Jack Conroy on Anna Bontemps plus some biographical data on the author.  It is good to know that the sage of Moberly, Mo. is giving out words of wisdom of his own in addition to the prepared travelling directions for keeping potential sinners on the straight and narrow path.
  But all kidding aside, we are looking forward to 1975 as a year of venture.  If successful, our mailing address will be somewhere on the isle of Exuma.  We'll let you know.

The very best to you both.
Dorry (and Zena)

[[in pencil in top margin]  Dorinson, Dorry
December   1975
Dear Jack and Gladys:

  I have now reached the age when I realize that writing to old friends at infrequent intervals is like fishing:  one never knows what goes on beneath the surface of the water.  Anyway, I hope this finds you both well and as reasonably content as the times and circumstances permit.   We get occasional snippets of information about you, Jack, in the book review pages of the papers.
  I retired early from my job last June - just couldn't put up with the meaninglessness of it any longer.  Zena give up her educational consulting at the same time; and so now both of us are not employed, but we are by no means people of leisure.  Zena is developing her long-dormant talent for painting and drawing in a very satisfactory way - purely amateur: she gives her work away to those who admire it.   I am finishing up the manuscript of a technical book I have been plugging away at for the past two years.   When that is done and disposed of, we plan to sell out up

here and build on our beachfront property on the island of Exuma in the Bahamas.  Although the project is looking less idyllic as time goes by, the two basic attractions still remain:  climate and absence of congestion.   We recently returned from a four weeks vacation there and are still in favor of the place.
With our best wishes and greetings
Dorry

pencil notes in top margin  Dorinson, Zena  [Dorinson 19 Dec  1980]
Dear Jack & Gladys:

  We're still basking in the Destin sunshine.  Dorry took time out from the last chapter of his book on Lubrication to go fishing with an old friend from the Ozarks (they even caught 7 sea trout!)  I'm painting, mostly portraits, and have a demonstration and workshop scheduled for the end of January.
   Saw your Stephen Wade listed in The New Yorker theatrical section - may the royalty go on & on.

printed text of holiday card  Best wishes for the holidays and for your happiness in the New Year
signature  Zena & Dorry

Dec. 19, 1981
Dear Jack -

  Another year finds us still here and doing much the same things.  Zena paints instead of writing.   I am the writer, but nothing you would approve:  a book on tribology which I am trying to flog to whatever publisher will have it.  It's hard going:  600 page technical books are very expensive to produce these days.
   We have an old friend from Missouri who is spending the winter here in one of the cut-rate off-season cottages on the Gulf.   He is from the Lake of the Ozarks region ...the kind whose one leg is shorter than the other so he can stand upright on the side of a hill without special effort.   We do a fair amount of reminiscing about things that happened forty years ago . . . a sure sign of advancing age but the only one that bothers me; the few bodily creaks and groans I have adjusted to as inevitable.

pencil notation in top margin    Dorinson, Zena
4-15-88
Dear Jack:

  I thought you might enjoy a limited close-up view of our town as seen in our local news.  Let me tell you, we've got everything from good ole boys to Jimmy Swaggerts.
  On the other hand, I have some very good, stanch,[sic]  friends, an art group which just voted to accept nudes in their big spring show, beautiful beaches (when you can get close enough thru the condos to see them) a library where you can find Walker Percy and "Beloved" as well as Danielle Steele, and

even some people who intend to vote for Jackson.

   I hope you are improving daily.   I just heard from Light, who didn't know I had your address and wanted to give it to me.   Your friends all care about you and wish you strength and a return to health.

Love,
Zena

[pencil notation in top margin]  Dorinson, Amos & Zena

12-19-85
Dear Jack--

   Jim Light keeps us informed of the follies and fortunes of the sage of Moberly, Mo.  That's how we heard about The Weed King.   Although the book stores here on the Red-Neck Riviera don't stock it, we were able to get a copy by special order.   There you are on the cover, waiting for a train on a track that goes nowhere, standing up big and bold.
  Best wishes for the year to come.

Zena/Amos Dorinson

File:Postcard with stone gate and horse-drawn carriage

St. Augustine City Gate

pencil note in top margin  Dorinson, Zena
postcard
Dorinson 3E 825 Indian Trail  Destin FL  32541
The Old City Gates St. Augustine, Florida     Now a part of Castillo de San Marcos National Monument, these pillars are the only remnants of an earthwork first built in 1704 and were once the main entrance to the ancient city.
postmark   PENSACOLA FL  325  PM  9 JUL  1983
Dear Jack:

   This card was one I found tucked away a month after our trip to Charleston and St Augustine.  The old town was fascinating -- those adobe walls are an artist's dream.   I am teaching kids again this summer and painting again.   Hope you are progressing at the speed of The Fast Sooner Hound!


Jack Conroy
Moberly Caring Center
Moberly, Mo.  65270

envelope
postmark  PENSACOLA FL  325  3 OCT 1988
Dorinson   3E  825 Indian Trail   Destin, FL  32541

Jack Conroy
℅ Carolee Hazlet
212 Crest D.
Moberly, MO  65270

note to left of address:  Answered

pencil note in top margin  Dorinson, Zena
10-2-88
Dear Jack:

   Isn't it strange how some of us turn out?  I now paint in water-color and oils - and teach private lessons in my studio here at home.   I exhibit in a very good gallery called Art Street in Ft. Walton Beach.   I may someday be the Grand-ma Moses of Mossey Cove!
  This is a far cry from the good old days when all your students at Abraham Lincoln were going to write the great American novel.  (I did write a novel, but it was so closely based on my experience in radio in Sioux City, Iowa and Sioux Falls, S.D. that I never tried for publication - to protect the guilty, I presume.  Doug Wilson writes you are as feisty as ever - (not his words) - glad for that!

Love, Zena

Greeting card
pencil notation in top margin    Dorinson, Zena  [Dec 24 1988]
Dear Jack:

   I just received a card from Jim Light - with that incredible picture of "Gentleman Jim" playing pater familias.   Is'nt [sic] it amazing!  Some of the kids even look like little angels.
   I am enclosing a photo taken at my last art show.  The friend who took it didn't do much for art - but I thought you might like the faint likeness in the lower, right corner.   Yep!  that's my boy:  Mark Dorinson, as painted by me, the Grandma Moses of Mossey Cove.
  Incidentally, we in the red-neck Riviera are getting slightly civilized:  for the first time since we've been here, I showed the nude in the left background.
  Hope this finds you continually improving.  I wish I could sign as usual, from both Dorry & me.  

Love, Z
Greeting card message   Wishing you the best of Holidays and the brightest New Year

pencil in top margin  Dorinson, Zena
12-4-89
Dear Carolee:

   You are much too modest - the picture is charming, especially since it is accompanied by family.
    I always appreciate your sending news about Jack.   I'm so glad he's still the same Jack inside, even if not outside.
   Here's something you could read him:

Dear Jack:

   I am enclosing a picture of Mark, taken when he and a couple of friends visited me in October for a whole week.  I'm sure you recognize the little boy who climbed on your lap and sat spell-bound as you read The Fast Sooner Hound and looked at the pictures with him.  The cap is on his head because he has turned into a bicycle nut and also a health nut, since he is maintenance manager for Universal Gym, who install equipment for spas, schools, health clubs, etc.  He still lives in

Steger, IL, and, besides his regular job, books and manages his band, doing very well on the suburban circuit.   He sends you his love and so do I.  Hang in there, dear Jack, as you've always done!
Much love,
Zena

pencil in top margin  n. d.
Dear Jack:

  I have sad news for you.  Dorry died last month on Oct. 9.  He had cancer and it advanced very quickly.  He died at home, where he wanted to be, and we scattered his ashes in the Gulf.
  You know he cherished your friendship for many years, just as I did.
  Be well --

With love,
Zena

Would you be so kind as to let me know where I may be able to buy some of your books?  And if you would consider placing copies of any of your books in the library at the museum you could get in touch with Mrs. Dera Gillespie at Bucklin, or Miss Iva Cannon.  I do  hope that you will visit the museum at Bucklin some day.  I just hope and pray that the Bucklin group can keep working on their project and see it grow each year.  It may not look like much to many people who have new buildings to place their museums in or fine old homes donated to be restored, but Bucklin is just a poor little old country town and that is the way that the way of life should be preserved.  Its hard keeping house (or museum) in an old building with little or no money, but thats Bucklin as it was, and thats what we want to see saved.

  Please excuse any mistakes in my typing and spelling, My dear great Aunt used to say "This pen I'm using can't spell worth a darn" so now I say this typewriter can't spell either and its nice and new..  The Aunt lived to be 98 and never lost her sence [sic] of humor and was a big influence on my life.   I enjoy older people and wonder and worry if my generation will ever make contented older people or will we be remembered as being too intrested [sic] in our own lives to care about anyone else!  How will our children remember us and our Grandchildren??
  Well the dirty laundry, dishes, and floors are still waiting on me so guess I better hang up now and give my attention to them.

signature  Sincerly [sic] Betty Dorrell
P.S.  Do  you  happen to know Amanda Greene?  She is a relative of mine on the Jobson side of the family and has always had an intrest [sic] in history.  Thought you might have know [sic]  her because of your mutual intrest [sic] in history.

[circled in top margin:  p 310]]

  He who departs remains chained to his memories, and he who stays abandons himself to painful longings.  And throughout the ages men and women have crouched on ruins, lamenting.

H Swenson  5662 Ridge Ave.
Mrs. Ina Weiner  26 2/8 W. Hersch St  Humboldt  7883
Harold Preece Tower Hotel  Del. 0416  24 W. Huron
Chris:  I 'm a good boy mother

letterhead  MICHIGAN STATE COLLEGE  EAST LASING  FOUNDED 1855 

                      SCHOOL OF SCIENCE AND ARTS  DEPARTMENT OF HISTORY AND POLITICAL SCIENCE


7 January 1946
Dear Mr. Conroy:

  Many thanks for remembering me with the Slappy Hooper piece.  I am the more pleased to have it since I am just starting a course in American Folklore, for the first time, and am launching it with a discussion of American demigods.   I don't have your new book as yet, but it is on my list and I intend to get it right away.  The Fast Sooner Hound is on my shelves.

Best wishes and thanks -
Dick Dorson

letterhead   MICHIGAN STATE COLLEGE   EAST LANSING

                       SCHOOL OF SCIENCE AND ARTS    DEPARTMENT OF HISTORY AND POLITICAL SCIENCE

March 1, 1948
Mr. Jack Conroy
6012 South Green Street
Chicago 21, Illinois
Dear Jack:
Thanks a million for your fine collection of Midland humor, and I cannot understand why it did not make a big splash, except perhaps because it had some quality to it.   I am going to have it reviewed for the SFQ.
With best wishes,
Sincerely yours,
signature  Dick
Richard M. Dorson
RMD:GHR
That was an evil-tempered letter I wrote you last time - I'd just got through correcting bluebooks, ugh.

letterhead  INDIANA UNIVERSITY    Bloomington, Indiana     Committee on Folklore    The Library,  Room 41
May 23, 1963
Mr.  Jack Conroy
14626 Millard Ave.
Midlothian, Illinois
Dear Jack:
Thank you very kindly for the ( underlined: book,  reprint, manuscript), titled The Disinherited
It was received in the Folklore office on May 21, 1963
Sincerely yours,
signatureDick
Richard M. Dorson
Chairman
Many thanks, Jack, and for your letter.   Dan Aaron  is an old friend of mine.  And Dan Boorstin tells me he saw you recently.

Provincetown  Mass
Dear Jack Conroy

  I've just read your Disinherited.  It's a fine piece of work   I didn't like your language in the narrative part so well, but when you are putting down what your people say, you put it down straight and salty - so darn few people writing have any feeling for the old English language as we speak it in these parts.   the whole thing seemed to me an absolutely solid unfaked piece of  crossed out:  work narrative, as good as the best of Jack London, and that in my opinion, is saying a great deal.  Congratulations

Yrs  J Dos Passos
For god's sake dont let them make a literary gent out of you.  A stuffed shirt is just as much stuffed if its colored red or white.   Your  writing  has so darn much life to it that the shirt stuffing artists are sure to be after you from all seven sides of the fence.  (If yr publishers want to use any of the above remarks - let 'em go ahead)

Dear Jack Conroy -

  I'm damn sorry - I havent been able to find time to write the Nation - If something turns up in the way of a piece I think you could use I'll send it on to you for Anvil  Best luck - Dont worry about your book - it's got good stuff in it & people will eventually get around to reading it -

Yrs
John Dos Passos

D.V.R. Drenner
503 Highland Rd.
Coffeyville, Kans.  67337
Dear Jack Conroy:

   I was reading Edward Dahlberg's CONFESSIONS about you, when the K.C. STAR piece arrived.  How this brings back memories of the  30's, especially since I am recovering from a CORONARY (MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION) and am not yet 60!   my wife sez from all that riotous living of the 30's & 40's.!
  Sorry my writing is also uncoordinated but recovery seems slow.
  Anyway, I'm pleased that you are getting some attention from the near-home folks.
  I haven't written much since I became a librarian, but perhaps if I live a few years so I can retire I may try again, after all, I did win the midwest Poetry Conpetions [sic] once!

Sincerely
Don v.R. Drenner

newspaper clipping with marginal hand-written comments
Old Hitch Lot Rich Source for Conroy Stories, Author Says

 A brief biographical sketch and picture of Jack Conroy of Chicago, who began his underlined: extensive  marginal comment:  how about that? your Press agent, mainly me, knows  writing career in Moberly appears in the May-June supplement of Chicago Schools Journal, an educational magazine for Chicago teachers.
 Conroy's brief biography tells:  "I was born in Moberly Missouri, just late enough to bid the nineteenth century goodby.  My memories of that mining and farming town and my experiences in or near it have gone into much of my writing, including the juveniles I wrote in collaboration with Arna Bontemps;  "The Fast Sooner Hound' 1942; 'Slappy Hooper, the Wonderful Sigh [sic] Painter,'  1946; and 'Sam Patch--the High, Wide and Handsome Jumper,' 1951.
  "A rich source of material was the old hitching lot behind the Merchants Hotel, where farmers on Saturday would hitch their nags and swap yarns while the womenfolk shopped.
  "The farmers usually chawed on hanks of homegrown tobacco as, to quote Kipling, 'regally they spat and smoked and fearsomely they lied'  some of their tales went into my stories in B. A. Botkin's "A Treasury of American Folklore" and with Arna Bontemps'  [[marginal comment:  enjoyed his sketch, [?] pic]] help some of them have emerged as books for children.  Other tall-tale books are on the way.
  "There's something of Moberly, too, in my two novels, "The Disinherited,' 1033, and 'A World to Win,' 1935, as well as in my anthology, 'Midland Humor: A Harvest of Fun and Folklore'.
  "My years of circled word: wondering marginal comment:   well?  as an itinerant worker helped me add to my collection of stories, if not to my material wealth.  Lately I've been leading a underlined word: sedate marginal comment:  hmmm life in Chicago as associate editor of the Standard Education Society.
  "Last Summer I visited Moberly, which also is the hometown of General Omar Bradley and of Elizabeth Seifert, underlined: novelist, marginal comment:  note editing and found the hitching lot replaced by a cold and austere municipal auditorium.
  "I wonder where the yarn-spinners congregate now."   marginal comment:  Tannehill Park

2-19-60
Dear Jack,

 How is the bucolic life?  I hope it is bucolic enough for this to reach you despite the lack of street address.
 The snow was nice for 3 days and then it became a great pain in the ass.  You got out just in time.
 I have a piece coming out in the Chi. Tribune Sunday Magazine on Kurt Vonnegut and his books and a class of his at Iowa.  Got $125 for it.  I sent it there because that mag. seems quite good now-a-days and, I don't think it is sour grapes, but Panorama seems dead since Kogan left.   One Anthony Monahan accepted the piece.  Said he didn't know when it would appear but I'm expecting it any week.
  You heard Algren got caught in an auto with some pot?  Don't know how serious that is, or was.  Are you writing?   What?
  I am going to N. Africa in April to catch foxes.  Really.

Regards,
Frank annotation in red ink:  (Dunlap)

Ap. 24 '67
Dear Jack,

 Very happy to hear about your award.  Congratulations. I saw the paperback at Tony Monahan's house but have not yet gotten my copy.
 Monahan is asst. editor of the Tribune Sunday Magazine, a nice young guy who says I write better than Milton Eisenhower who will soon have a pile of Republican crap in the Sunday Mag.
 I am leaving for Tangier, Morocco on May 7 and Donna and I would like to have you and Gladys over for dinner any evening before that if you could make it.  Tony Monahan & his wife Bea would come also, and Monahan is anxious to meet you.
 If you can make it give Donna a ring at the pet shop LI9-2031 (2222 N. Clark St) anytime, or call us here evenings 327-3596,  We're at 2924 N. Burling.
 Hope to see you for a supper evening.  I may be eaten by a lion and never see you more.  My piece comes out May 7.

Best,
Frank

Fri. Oct. 27 '67
Dear Jack,

  Got to at least start a letter to you.  Been so long.
  I don't think I even sent you a card from Morocco.  Actually I often did not have the money for stamps.  That means it was a very interesting trip.   I learned to sleep through bed bug attacks.  First came in the medina of Fes, an out-of-this-world place in all respects.  Was there for 3 days of the 5-day war.  Nobody bothered me or with me.  I did not see a Caucasian three for 2 days very strange effect on me - I did not know the state of warfare, just that there was trouble there, and the few radios drew crowds of Marocs chooking [sic] the narrow streets to martial music and Hitlerian bombast:  I had an idea things were awry.  Nothing much resulted from the war, in Morocco.  Was back in Tangier where the American library was broken up and were a couple of demonstrations and many rumors.   Found a pretty American chick so we became friendly.  Was (in the way of the 'East') smoking grass one night in our penthouse-like rooms with a view of the Straits and Spain, my head resting on the wall when an explosion knocked my head soundly on the wall.  It went on and I got up to see artillery clouds of blue smoke drifting over the bay in near darkness.  In my state I envisioned that wondrous Dyan (Sp?) initiating a great pincer movement by taking Tangier. "Gobble the bastards up!" was my feeling.  marginal note:  Was just a 21 gun salute!  I could see the Jews attacking Cairo by taking every North African country consecutively from Morocco on.  There were times when I did not care for the Moroccans.
  Stayed there 3 months and ran out of money in Marrakech in mid-July.  It is

at the foot of the Atlas about 100 miles from the Sahara.  Wound up in a medina flop house.  One afternoon hit 130º F. and mornings came on in the 90ºs.  Learned to live with the bugs.  It was memorable.  Came finally to Lisbon whose greenery and generally well-to-do people was like a visit to heaven.  Jetting over the Atlantic from Lisbon (my first jet across) stunned me.  After Morocco I honestly could speak to no one in N.Y. for 24 hours.

  Most valuable aspect was that I woke up.  Cummings:  "The ears of my ears are open - The eyes of my eyes can see."  Now and since, the greatest struggle and most important is not to go to sleep again at all in this life.   If this sounds mystical or over-grand, it is no less real.
  Did you see the May 7 Trib article on Vonnegut?   Got a few assignments from the Trib I hope to get to work on soon.  Morocco raised a book plan and 3 articles in progress.
  Most wonderful thing for writers these days:  Hollywood can't keep up with TVs demand for movies - which means a need for stories which need will grow.  Nice.
  I understand you are on your autobiog.  What will be finished when?  I thought of doing an article on you in your bucolic (?) surroundings.
  Hope to hear from you and of what is happening.  Say hello to Gladys.  Donna says "hi".

Best,
Franklin

Thurs 2-22-'68
Jack,

  Copied down all I could for your article - facts - to get it to you hastily.
  Perrill and I had a tremendous time.
  Never would have missed it for anything.
  So impressed us - because also we talked for 30 hours going, and coming that we were both struck - independently - of doing - each - a book on the trip. -
  But I understand it is not so easy to do books - will get an article out of it at the least.
  Hope your head was OK.
  Can't tell  you how much the visit meant to me and to John.
  We respect you and what youve done emensely [sic]  - and it is valuable to us.
  More later.  Want to get this off.
  Please write an autobiog.  We want to read it.
  You give us impetus like high octane.

Best.
Franklin

 John is sending poems.
 I'll send on your wrench, pliars [sic] & screwdriver - we needed them about 20 times.  All was well in the end.

Sun. 9-15-68
Dear Jack

  Hows things?  I got in one demonstration march just because I felt you would approve, and sat in the street as the Guard slapped on their gas masks, cops moved down along the building walls and a troop-carrier rumbled up before us with a machine gun on its top, all crying as the NBC truck came up "The whole world watches!", very moving, and the red flag flapped against my cap.   No gas that afternoon so I figured myself a winner and went home.
  Which is rather mobile and indistinct now as Donna's and my divorce went through in June.   Somewhere there is a lack of communication, and must be my fault or maybe I would have a book out by now.
    I certainly do have your wrench and screwdriver and pliers still but I guess all writing types are no good, or that is what my first wife implied.   If you could overlook that temporary breach of faith I would ask a favor of you:
   Would you drop Spectopsky (?)   (I think that is his name, and think he is a friend of yours) a note, the articles editor, I think, at Playboy, and recommend me for a copy writing job at Playboy?   I am very tired of washing walls and it does not seem profitable.   I had such a job lined up at Monse Wards, but I failed the EYE EXAM.  Some humor, huh?  It would have been OK on the basis of my 4 articles, the last being the Vonnegut piece of May 7 '67 in

the Tribune Sun. Mag., but I failed the eye part of the physical.  Absurd, of course.

   Need a job at present to pay back bills and want to get ahead on the Support money.
   I know women who copywrite for Playboy and I never saw a woman who could write better than a man.   I phoned over there myself (to the personnel dept.) and they said they would mail an application to hold on file, but that they were doing no hiring now.
  Please let me know if you can put in a word for me, or if you can't for some reason, I of course accept it.
  What did you think of Perrills poems?
   Hope you [sic] summer has been good and hope work goes well for you.   I won't even mention the tools again, just have faith, although, despite your tracts, I know it doesn't unscrew nuts.
   At the moment I'm analyzing The Dolly Dolly Spy by Adam Diment, a cool, hip spy novel, to see  how I can make one of my own and become filthy rich.
   Were it not for women and money I think I might be doing something worth-while - but who knows.   Hope you are well and that all things are.

Best,
Frank

Sat. Oct. 26 '68
Dear Jack,

   At last!  At last my character has uprighted itself and here are your long-lost tools back.  And as a thankyou I include one other which you may find handy incase you want a round hole in anything.
   All this explains I got a paycheck.  It has been unnerving working steady hours, but the money is a welcome change.
   I found out that Ozark Airlines (which service Moberly) has a weekend plan.   You can fly anywhere in their system (Denver, Chi., Minneapolis etc.) for $30 if you leave on Sat. and get your return (or last) flight by 6 pm the next day, Sunday.   Might be handy if you come to Chi. for a weekend.  One guy (wrote an article about it) flew 3700 miles for $30.
   I am working on a spy novel, and when and if I'll show it to you.
  Holt did a great thing in publishing Malreaux's book Anti Memoirs.  He's rather an international Conroy?  Was that the idea?  With a dash of mysticism.
  I understand Algren is on the government investigation panel of the Chi. riots.
  I am avoiding marriage - one good step toward publication.
  Mid-November I expect to have a coach-house near Old Town with 2 bedrooms - $65 a month so if you come to town and would like a bed you're welcome.
  Kogen is back in books.  Was that a demotion or a pro- ?  Or is he a romantic?
  Best to your wife and hope you don't have to use any of these tools.  Actually herein is contained about all that is necessary to take America apart, isn't it.

Best,
Franklin
printed in ink beneath signature:  DUNLAP

Dear Sage,

  My pen seems to be going.  Penrod worries about his looks going.  Everything is going.  Prices up, wages down.  I don't care at all since I don't work.  Can't buy anything anyway.
   Thanks very much for the New Letters and the inscription.  It shall be one of my treasured books.  And I thought the prices were fine.   The Field of Coollen Colow was superb writing.  I liked it I think better than any of your stuff I've read. note in left margin:  Lady living with me thought it was great.   I was sorry to see if end.  One thing is clear, you should have written more of your own stuff.  I hope you are now - it is really fine, quality stuff.  I enjoyed the interview, too.  Especially the last words of wisdom:  Don't let the bastards grind you down.  You know it.  I'm (just finished) doing a piece on Vachel Lindsay's kid Nick (45 years old) who is a poet at Goshen College  (poet-in-residence) Goshen, Ind.  He met Frost in the last year of Frost's life.  Nick was in grad. school taking a free government ride there.  Frost told him not to get the degree.  said:

"Don't
Join
The certified.
Give 'em hell,
The bastards!"

  Nick didn't get it either.  I sold a piece to AP News - $50.  Interview of that lady who started the Dont Wear Fur Coats thing.  Hack work.  Got a review from Kogan.  I'm tired of the Trib pieces - about 17 of them.   They cut all the quality till I'm ashamed to see my name on them.  From now on they get shit, which is what they want.  No more taking

3 months on a piece.  Two weeks.  And I want to do very few.  Maybe none.  I'm looking for a cabin in the red woods.  No electricity is OK.  Tired of paying for the luxuries.  I just want to do a book.

   Thanks for the agent add.   I wrote but he won't place articles or SSs.  Said send a novel.  I don't have one.  But its high time to get one so that's what I'll do.
   I agree with all your political notes and its refreshing to hear a man over 50 state some with some sense to them.  How did you happen to stay alive when nearly everyone else is a zombie.  Good old Jack.  Tell it like it is.
   After that autobiog  I hope you sit down and tell the world how it is.  What you don't know they haven't thought of yet.  I don't know what good it would do you other than whatever good writing does any writer, but people could use it - like a little artificial respiration.
  I hope the book comes out of the New Letters issue.
  I knew Siegel died. 
  The pix of you were good too.
   Change on O Savonarola bouncing them left and right.

Your friend,
Frank

Dear Jack,

  I have had everything on West read for several weeks now.  It sits on the desk in a pile and defies me to find some take-off point.
  With the immanent (I am a rotten speller)  Mexico fellowships date almost here I have been working on a new novel, trying to get enough words for submittal.   Mexico informed me that this year they wold probably not take North Americans for fellowships, but rather other Latin Americans, but to querry [sic] them again in May, which I shall do.  Damn luck - I felt like I had a chance this year and they decide (probably) against North Americans.  I think that is wonderful for the Latin Americans however.  If  you were a struggling writer in  back-water village in Honduras, say, who on earth would you expect to give you a poet's pension.  But still it does me little good.
  Next week I will try getting off the ground with West.  We have an apartment (a real dump) in Old Town which needs a lot of work and that too cuts into the underlined: time.   Moving there May first.
  Donna and I would like to visit you and your wife some evening before then.  Would like your wife to meet her and like to talk to you.  Maybe bring along what I have on the proposed  book - a sort of Don Quixote - Tin Drum (Gunner Grass) in America - a strenuous stab at the AMERICAN theme - ideals over practicality.   Where wanders Motley now?

Regards   Frank
added in ink:  DUNLAP

Jan.  18 '73
Dear Jack,

   I certainly thought Bonny Bill and I would have returned down Highway #24 out of the fog into the garden of Moberly long before now to see you Savonarola, but so the world bends.
   Penrod and I are in the midst of one of our snits.   He is holed up in the Hammond basement 5909 Columbia Ave, Hammond.  He sold a piece you will like to see in the February underlined:  Gallery - supposedly it will be out then, and completing his novel.  He rarely rises from the bsmt, so he must be completing the novel.
   Perrill quit driving a taxi in Chicago and is doing a 2-page piece for underlined: OUI for $500 on cigars.
   After 15 Tribune pieces and nothing else I escaped to a shed beside the Pacific.  I hear the sea like a Moberly coal train.  Trying to do a novel on the sex life of Mennonites.  Kaggan was to finance me with book reviews but haven't heard a word from him.  He must have gone to his reward.
   Very exciting, the New Letters.  When I get a couple bucks I'll write them for a copy, I'd like to see it very much.  Is the autobiog about ready for book form?  I'd like to do a Trib Mag piece on you some day - maybe I can stop in Moberly if I ever head East.   I'm doing a piece from notes gathered before on Nick Lindsay, a mad carpenter-poet, son of Vachel Lindsay for the Trib.  Why don't you write up the old festive days of ?  and Algren and you for Playboy or Esquire, or me interview you on it.  Or could we rob a train?  Or the Moberly 1st National?  I didn't know how desperate writers got but I'm finding out.  Or slip a chapter lively and full of names to Mark Zussman

at Esquire, a receptive fellow. - a chapter of the Autobiog.

   Do you have a New York agent?  I have some pieces and would like an agent to ship them around but I don't know one.   Or are they really little help?
   How is Madam Queen?  Well I hope.
   Right next to the sea here it is about 60º days but much Pacific NW rain and fog.  I drove a $50 Ford from Chi through Canadian Rockies out here in October.  Beautiful, but strangely I miss that Chi icy sleet and the horrifing [sic] winds.  I must be crazy.  Which would explain a lot of things.
    Sorry I haven't seen you lately Jack, would like to, and maybe in a while.  Keep up the good show in the mags.

Frank
PO Box 23
Westport, Calif.
95488

in pencil in top margin:  Dunlap, Frank
Wilderness Road
Branscomb, Calif.  95417
Feb. 17, 1976
Dear Jack,

   It has been a while since I wrote to you or heard from you.  May you be prospering toward heaven wherever you are or whatever you are doing.
   I moved inland from that little town of Westport where I lived on the coast, 12 miles into the redwoods of the coastal range.   It is Beautiful here and a high valley with a river running thru it and beautiful people, ladies first of all, children and even the men.  Nature seems to drive out the wild beast from the heart and then some love can grow for others and the world, so it seems.   So I am happier than I knew before that you got out of Chicago, as a character in Jack London said:  "What do you want, Martin Eden, in these sick cities of men, go back to your sea and ships."  And so  you went back to your country and I found  one of my own.
   Still working on the novel I began in 1973.  It is 1400 pages of unpruned chaos.  Yet I hope for it.  I want to call it Miss Amerika.  I live in a plastic dome in the redwood forests I made from bent saplings.  But presently I have the luxury of a cabin because the lady owner is vacationing in Wyoming.  Wish you were here for a talk, oh Sage.
   Of Willie Penrod:  He got a chapter of his novel in The New American Review which paid him $50 (oh tem brevis - as you might say).  That was about a year ago.   I haven't talked

to him for 2 years since we punched each other out up at a farm in Michigan.  He works heroically on in his Hammond basement so far as I know.

   Perrill - the pretty boy poet - is living in northern Michigan writing on a novel the last I heard a year ago.
   Algren went to live in New Jersey I heard.  Probably close to some racetrack.
   A girl up a lonely road here in the hills has a copy of THE DISINHERITED in her old weathered bookcase so we were friends right away.
   The area where I live is much the same as the Big Sur coast of Miller and that Robinson Jeffers described.  Beautiful.  Like all the world.  Like even the fields around Moberly.
   Ah, yes, Jack, I discern that it is not literature that lasts nor is it literature that we seek, but something of the soul, huh?   There is something in each of us that is guide and destination and it is that which outlives even masterpieces and that is where we will find our Joy.  I hope you have found yours and that each day goes well with you.  Did you print anymore of the autobiography, or anything else recently?  May your pencil never dull.

Love,
Frank Dunlap

pencilled annotation in top margin    Dunlap, Frank [1978]
Hi Jack,

  How you doing?  I'm still in this world.   Hope you are too so we may more readily communicate.  I'm in a fine little cabin back in the redwoods doing the bachelor thing and trying to finish underlined:  Miss Amerika which I've been at 5 years.  Maybe by June.  I did a novella called underlined: the Wave about this area and it's come back from Doubleday and Knopf.  No 4 bucks to send it out again, but by and by.
  I'm returning this interview I've had for a couple years.  I thot [sic] I'd lost it.  Sorry about that, but happy to find it.
  I got a horse in Montana last year and rode him across Idaho to Baker, Oregon where I broke my wrist.  Maybe ride him on down here in summer.  Penrod finished his novel and it bounces around publishers now.  We aren't talking still.  Willie gets his snits.  Perrill lives here up the mountain and is finishing a novel.
 What's with your writing and other activities?  The autobiog?  You in OK health?  What's with Algren?
  Do you have an agent now?  Any clues on where to send a novel?
  The weather is wet but warm out here.  Beautiful place.
  Let me hear your voice, oh Sage, if you're still ramblin' around.  And all the best to you,

Frank Dunlop

Penrod supposed to have a story in Cavalier Mag. Nov. or Dec. under the pseudonym Penney Rhodes titled underlined:  A Very Special Gift.
  He had another chapter of his novel accepted by North American Review, the third one they will have printed.

pencilled notations in top margin  circled:  Dunne   Dunne, Thomas  [no date]
Manusmore
Clare Castle
Co Clare
Hello Jack & Gladys

  What a pleasent [sic] surprise I got when I recieved [sic] your Christmas Card.  Please forgive me for not getting in contact with you all this time, but while in England I Completely mislaid your address, & it Certainly was nice hearing from you again.  As you have probably noticed from my address I am now living in Ireland.  I came home just over 1 year ago & my brother Patrick came home 3 years ago.  He is a Taxi driver at Shannon Airport & I am working in a garage in the Airport.  The above address is 11 miles from the Airport.

II
I was in London for 6 yrs & liked it very much, but I think one alsways [sic] likes to come home after a certain amount of time.  Patrick got married 1 yr ago & I was married last August, so we are both married since you last heard from us.  Patrick bought a house down here in Clare & I am hoping to build one later on, probably the end of the year.
I hope yourself & the Mrs have been keeping well all this time.  Do you still travel round as often as you used to do, & have you written any more books?  I hope you  had an enjoyable Christmas.  We had a very good Christmas here.
I will be looking forward to hearing from you in the near future.  Patrick & Frances sends [sic] their kindest regards.  P.T.O.

I would like to take this opportunity of wishing you & Mrs Conroy a very happy & prosperous new year.
Bye for now
Yours truly
Thomas & Anne Dunne

12/22/53
Dear Jack:

 Thanks for note and card.  I've recently completed a 3-act Play - miscengenation [sic] in New Orleans.  It seems good to me, but I know it will have a hard time getting anywhere.
 Have you heard of a new publishing firm - Cameron & Kahn, Inc.  109 Greenwich Ave. N.Y.C  ?
 The Cameron is Geo. Cameron, formerly Ed-in-Chief at Little, Brown - a fine man, and his new house sounds good.
 Things are sure tough, aren't they, boy!

Murrell

New Orleans
April 3, 1974
Dear Jack,

  I received your latest letter on the same day I had mailed one to you, and this is a little postscript to that one.   I was moved and impressed with a small section of the letter dealing with your part in the burial of your grandfather...
  "The farm went on and Grandpa died and I helped to dig his grave.  Some thot it awful I dug some of the earth to put him in - I didn't - I thot it nice I had something to do with putting Grandpa away - something personal like.  I thot, Grandpa, your grandson, who loved you very much, is tucking you away.  That's what I thought as I dug the hard earth.  Near Israels Gap in Albemarle County, Virginia.  I dug memories and love into the earth and it was covered up and few remember anymore.  Nothing is left by a grave and memories and how many of us remember memories?"
  That's what I call some real honest-to-God writing, Jack, and I congratulate you.

Sincerely,

Mr. Jack Conroy  6012 S. Green St., Chi. 21
Dear Mr. Conroy:  My date of 1947 was wrong.  The first time the Ballad of Kansas City was printed was some 21 years previously.  You have my permission to print it under that name and edit it to suit your requirements.... I had intended to send you several similar Ballads such as "Mark Twain,"  "John L. Sullivan,"  "The Roosevelts," and some selections from the Great AMERICAN ASS, but I was called back to work at the Hotel Kansan here, and my hours are so long and laborious that I cannot even send you the copy of underlined:  The Great American Ass.  It is not in my hands, but is lent to a newspaper woman who seems to be writing a magazine article about me.  underlined:  Biographical notes b. Wilber, Neb. Sept 6. 1881.  At that time Willa Cather was an 8-year-old girl from Virginia in Wilber, a Bohemian center.  Grad. Kas. Uni. 1904.  Columnist on K.C. Star till 1912.  [[underlined:  " AN ARKANSAS MAN ON BROADWAY" 1912-1914.  Hillbilly humor in N.Y. Evening MAIL.  Tis was the first of the " - - - ON Broadway" Columns.  In 1922 Brentanos published my

underlined  Jack Conroy letter April 22, '47 Page Two
book "underlined:  "The Gentle Art of Columnizing," A Treatise on Newspaper Humor -- Brentano's published 'THE ASS" anonymously in 1926.  I am now finishing off a dramatic novel, a "serio-comic" to use the old British jargon, dealing with the rise of pictures to pre-eminence in American life.  The movie, the comic strip, the animated cartoon. . . til cartoon characters are far more real to the voters underlined:  than the Republican candidates for the Presidency!  My wife Lena Fern Edson works in K.C. Mo.  My daughter Helen underlined: Poe Edson teaches school in Kansas City Kansas.  She is 39 years old She is descended from The Edgar (Allen) Poe family, thru her mother.  Through me she is descended from the Mayflower Pilgrims, double underline: John Alden and double underline:  Priscilla  (Molines)

  I hereby agree to Jack Conroy's terms for including my Ballad of Kansas City in his anthology

Sincerely, C. L. Edson  Topeka, Kas  Shawnee County  April 22, 1947

letterhead  CHARLES M. EK   1812 N. PURDUM STREET  KOKOMO, INDIANA
Sept 22" - 1943.
Dear Comrade: -

  I have your letter dated March 7"- '43.  I do not remember whether I have answered it or not.   I am getting my oldest neice [sic] to write this letter for me.  On June 4th - 1943 I was stricken with paraleys [sic] on my right side.   I have not taken a step since.  I manage to sit up about an hour each day.  I still read some and listen to the radio.  My arm and leg give me some pain.  I do not have time to discuss the war with you, much as I would like to.  My son is in N. Africa somewhere.  I do not know where, or what he is doing.  I may as well have used a postal card for all I am saying.  There is no indication that I shall ever improve.  But when I think of so many young men dying on the battle field I become fully reconciled to my fate.  I had many plans made for 1943.  In fact I had made a trip the day before I was stricken.  I was to go the next day on a trip with Butler U.  I think of my many trips the last ten years.  I had become a specialist on Sedges, but all these belong to the past.  I am at home and I receive good care.  Some days I listen to a dozen news broadcasts.  We shall gain a military victory but loose [sic] the war on the home front.  I hope you are doing well with your books, reviews and articles.  I regret I shall have to

stop.  My oldest neice [sic] who is writting [sic] this is due home.
Very Comradely Yours
Chas. M Ek.

3
Naturally, I am hoping you will actively support the magazine.  I think you share many or enough of the views in the announcement, and in any case a lot of this is open to discussion and revision.   That is why we're circulating the announcement in a draft version.  You probably have your own plans and are quite busy--but I hope you can send us some writing for the first issue and will think about taking part on any level you like--from active to honorary editor, down the line.
The magazine will be produced in a very professional way, high standards for its appearance.  We have the help of a professional designer.  I assume it will be a little magazine format, though that will be decided by the editors later.  We will plan a circulation of a few thousand from the start, anything less is not worthwhile.  (If that sounds fanciful, we have supporters in a number of different cities who will place it in bookstores and otherwise dispose of it; and we will use large mailing lists as well.)
Money is not the obstacle we have to get past at this point.  We have to involve from the start enough people from different places toensure [sic] that the magazine will not be narrow, small or uninteresting.
One line whited out
By the way, do you have a name for a magazine put away in some drawer somewhere that you could give us?  "New Voices" is provisional, in fact bound to be changed.  sounds trite to me.  Other suggestions made have been:  New Writing, Reflections, New Realities, Realities, Messages, and (excuse the theft) Unrest.  What do you think of these--or do you have any other suggestions?
note in bottom margin is inserted here as indicated by a line  By the way, local bookstores are all "out" of underlined:  Jack Conroy Reader when I tried to get hold of it, right after the reviews in The Sun Times  & Tribune.  They've [underlined: still]] out of stock today.
Burt Franklin neverreplied [sic] to my requests for review copies.  A few days ago I called them up and they promised to send one right away.  I will definitely review it, and will use the interview as background, maybe for an accompanying article.  I was not crazy about the interview--you deserved a better journalist than me - partly because it compares rather unfavorably to the others you have given; andthis [sic] is why I haven't use it in the Call up to now.
Are you still considering reviewing Glenn's book?
Why aren't you listed as VIP for the Kansas City Cultural Conference?  Weren't you invited?  I'll be there, almost certainly, and hope to see you then.
Best,
Paul Elitzik (pen name Reid)
written in left margin   P. S.  If you don't feel writing a letter but want to talk, why not drop me a note telling me to call you up?   I can use the WATS line at the Call office or you can telephone me and I'll return the call.  office  312-341-9743

letterhead  ELLINGER  Missouri House of Representatives - 111th District     File:Photograph of representative Ellinger

Dear Jack,

  No, this is underlined: not a request for a campaign contribution!  However I ought to get underlined:  something out of my copaign [sic] besides "experience."  (I keep having good "experiences" in my life, but sometimes wonder when the real thing will begin!
   A while back I read your review of Quentin Bell's biography of Virginia Woolf.  Fine review, great, & all that.  I couldn't help but notice, however, what to me is a very interesting biographical lapse.  What!, no mention that Quentin had a brother - - equally a nephew of the great predecessor of Sylvia Plath, named Julian.   The latter having been considered one of the most promising of young British poets died fighting for the right side in Spain.  He was a favorite of Ms. Woolfe too [sic] boot.  What would Mike Gold ever think!
   Enjoyed reading the first chapter of your autobiography in underlined:  New Letters.  Hope to see the whole thing as it emerges.
  I still aim to make good on finding some material in the official manuscripts concerning all your family members killed in the mines at Monkey's Nest.
  Edith & Bob say hello.
  My best to you 

Best regards,
Rory Ellinger

pencil note under letterhead  E. Ely-Estorick
3:9:'54
Dear Jack,
So good to hear from you and make contact again!  Listen, Jack, to hell with the alleged proletarian-critico-literary ecclesiasts.  Your novel has earth and sun and man and machine - and how good it was for me to have reaffirmed the life that becomes only an abstract sense in the chaos of NY.  I have always admired you, Jack, even before I ever wrote to you.  I've always been aware of the pioneer work you are doing.  You see, you're down to earth, and when the decisive days come the breath of the soil will be within you and your heart will beat with the new order - and where will the bleating jackasses be, on probably where they spend many of their inspirational hours having their balls scratched in the bohemian studios of some muchly married amorosa.  Most of these literary bastards need a big city like New York in which to unburden their pathological natures.

   Of course I'll send you a few copies of Trend.  As for handbills, we had some printed, but their [sic] sleazy as hell, so I won't send a batch, only a couple for you.  Send me a batch of overleafs.  I'll send them along wherever possible.
   How's Anvil getting on?  Isn't there a Jan-Feb issue, or have I slipped up?

April 3

 I've  had an eye operation - and its left me on the shelf - I'm pretty low!  But will write soon.

pencil note in top margin  Embree, Charles
letterhead  WALT DISNEY PRODUCTIONS
27 Mar 1976
Dear Jack:

  I can't tell  you how sorry I am about the tragic illness of your daughter,  "Why is it that most people are better than what happens to them?" asked Naomi Bliven in a recent book review.  A haunting question.

  When you have time would you please send me the address of underlined: December Magazine.  I'm sure it's sold out here, but I don't know where.  Am looking forward to reading "The Morphadite."  

  Loved your post card -- a work of art.  And a valuable addition to the Archives.

  Am enclosing my latest product of Phracture Filosophy.  No comment called for.   Just want you to see what your apprentice sage is up to.

  Kindest regards to Gladys.

Yrs
C.B.
printed in bottom margin:  No Agreement Will Be Binding On This Corporation Unless In Writing And Signed By An Officer

pencilled note in top margin:  Embree, Charles
19 June 1977
Dear Jack:

  Loved "The Morphadite."  My only complaint is the usual one:  the piece came to an end too soon, leaving me wanting more.
  You really catch Moberly.  I am fascinated by the fact that the town changed so little between your generation and mine.  I mean, I had the same experiences you did generally and often specifically.  My friends and I too wondered about "Morphodites," and our reasonings had the same twists and turns as yours and your friends!  Within the phenomenon called regional culture I wonder if there existed in those days a narrower strictly local culture which passed down from generation to generation.  I wonder if us Moberly boys don't have shared experiences different even from, say, Columbia boys.
  Hope this finds you and Gladys well.  Nothing very interesting has been happening at this end, which is why I have been unusually mum.

Best, C.B.
note in red ink beside initials:  Embree

Jack:
Let's hope the book-publishing business undergoes a revolution soon - though such seems unlikely.  Our warmest wishes to Gladys for improved health.  I trust that the autobiography is marching.
C.B.

pencilled note in top margin   Embree, Charles  [1980]
holiday greeting card
printed message:  and Happiness throughout the New Year
from Barbara and your poor correspondent,  C.B.

pencilled note in top margin  Embree, Charles B.
8 June 1980
Dear Jack:

   I want to congratulate you on underlined:  The Jack Conroy Reader.  The appreciative response to it must be gratifying to you.  I have followed with great joy the reviews, from the one in underlined: Publishers Weekly   (which mistakenly gave Kentucky credit belonging to Missouri) to Studs Terkel's beautiful job.  Enclosed is the one from today's Los Angeles underlined: Times.
   Congratulations also on the new editions of underlined: The Disinherited !  You have achieved, among other things, the one dream all writers share, I think -- the dream of producing a classic.  Immortality - she is sweet!
   Barbara joins me in wishing you continued success.  May the Conroy reputation grow and grow and grow - that justice may be seen to be alive and well in the world.
   Our best, too, to Gladys.

C.B.
P.S.:  the photo is terrific.  I have another copy of the underlined:  Times' review which I am keeping.  C.

Birmingham Ala.
Dear Jack -
You never know how how much I enjoyed hearing from you.   I have thought about you many times and wondered what you were doing. and I am glad you remember me.   I received the book and am reading and enjoying it.  I always wanted a copy of your book But couldnt ever find one.  I have been down here thirty years.  Am retired from the U.S. Steel.  doing OK on S.S. and pention. [sic]
I was in Gary East two unclear words and Misigan City before I came here and I like Birmingham very much  Climate and all.  I have a Sister in Moberly and I try and visit her every Summer. and if I am abel [sic] and nothing happens I want to come up there this Summer and dont worry I have ? will come to see you.  Not many left around there that I know any more.  the 22 Strike Seems like a dream now.

2
I have never regreated [sic] leaving there in fact I think I did a whol [sic] lot better here.  I only hated to See all thoes [sic] old men lose their jobs and never abel [sic] to get another.  it didnt heart [sic] we young fellows because we could get jobs.  Well I was in the Hospital nine days and am glad to be back home they thought I  had anouther [sic] Heart attack but it was just a bad case of angina.  I hope you can read this I cant write so good any more it is quite an effort.  I noticed the price on your book So to Show you how much I enjoy haveing [sic] it I am enclosing a Check.  
Will close now  Sure was glad to hear from y. [sic]
G B Englen

Maurice English  TEMPLE UNIVERSITY PRESS   Philadelphia, Pa.  19122
10 Oct 69
Dear Jack,
Many thanks for your letter - I phoned Mr Angione, whom I wanted to meet anyway. & he invited me - However, my wife is joining me in Phila about then, and I don't know when she'll be arriving - But I or we will make it, if we possibly can -- and to the symposium preceding the saturnalia too, if possible.   Will you be staying over?  Where Michael Fabre?
Cordially,
Maurice

Postcard showing barbed wire fence, horses and row of small buildings (tabby huts).

post card:   OSSABAW ISLAND SAVANNAH, GEORGIA
postmark:  U.S. POSTAL SERVICE  313   PM  25 NOV  1975
Mr. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Av
Moberly, Mo  65270
24 Nov 75
Dear Jack:
How goes it with you?  I've taken 2 months leave to get some writing done on this barrier island - once a slave plantation (they lived in the tabby huts) - was reverted to jungle & marshland, with alligators, rattlesnakes, poets, painters and philologists.  Almost too fascinating to get any work done.
Best regards
Maurice English

pencil notation in top margin:  Erisman, Robert
12/25/57   from Robert O. Erisman
Dear Jack:  Your extra-beautiful card was a real delight, and promises to survive the post-Xmas dissolution of the Xmas card display.  Sorry I couldn't reciprocate in kind but the state of our present income didn't allow for cards this year.  I've had my hands on something several times but haven't been able to hang onto anything yet.  You might be interested, if you get a chance, to see the current, January, issue of underlined:  Living, in which is a little piece on our house that Little Jack built - and I'm still hoping that underlined: someday you'll get to see it in person.  and I'll have a piece in February or March underlined:  Atlantic that should amuse you.
All best,
Bob

  Thanks very much for your explicit and very helpful sketch of the book-reviewing situation in Chicago.   The N.Y. Herald, The Christian Science Monitor, & the Providence (R.I.) Journal have all said hey'd call on me for an occasional "round up" of Westerns, for unmentioned honorarium.  Hope your family troubles will lighten (? underlined:  Niece grandchildren!  We never had the courage to multiply in this dandy world).  Again sincere thanks, & all best, Bob

postcard
pencil notation in top margin   [1958] Erisman, Robert
Dear Jack:  greatly appreciated your sending our "Laughing Frontier;"  my wife and I both enjoyed having another good hunk of Conroy copy;  have re=read your books repeatedly, wanting this.  Reason I've responded so slowly, and reason this note isn't typewritten, is I got landed another good wallop.  for the past year they've been coming thick and fast but this took the cake.  Some nervous business paralyzed my whole left side, so that I had to give up good newspaper job I'd waited 6 months for, and pass up good Civil Service job I'd put in for recently (technical writer, at nearby Navy Underwater Lab.). so I'm immobilized, wife trying to earn our living, never having worked before.  Neurologist won't predict when and if paralysis will end:  Charming.  Bob

greeting card
pencil notation in top margin  Erisman, Robert  [1959]
Best wishes for Christmas and the New Year
Bob Erisman

greeting card
It was good to have your annual note as usual; its warm and generous and intelligent spirit always gives me something that I could only call a religious feeling  - which I rarely get elsewhere unfortunately.  Not much better here - like you, can claim to be alive, but that about covers it.  Next year, by heck, it will be different!  All best, Bob
